docs.title: Ableton MCP Extended
docs.text: Control Ableton Live using natural language via AI assistants like Claude or Cursor.

docs.title: What is Ableton MCP Extended?
docs.text:
Ableton MCP Extended is a powerful Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that bridges AI assistants with Ableton Live, enabling you to control your DAW through natural language conversations.

Transform Conversations into Music

👤 "Create a brief minimalist/neo-classical composition..."
🤖 "Creating MIDI clips... Adding effects... Done!"

Watch Video Demonstration

docs.title: 🎹 Session and Transport Control
docs.text:
• Start and stop playback
  • Get session info (tempo, time signature, track count)
  • Set tempo and control transport

docs.title: 🎚️ Track Management
docs.text:
• Create, rename, and get detailed information for MIDI and audio tracks
  • Control track properties: volume, panning, mute, solo, and arm
  • Manage track grouping and folding states

docs.title: 🎵 MIDI Clip and Note Manipulation
docs.text:
• Create and name MIDI clips with specified lengths
  • Add, delete, transpose, and quantize notes
  • Perform batch edits on multiple notes
  • Adjust clip loop parameters and follow actions

docs.title: 🎛️ Device and Parameter Control
docs.text:
• Load instruments and effects from Ableton's browser
  • Get full list of parameters for any device
  • Set and batch-set device parameters (normalized 0.0-1.0)

docs.title: 📂 Browser Integration
docs.text:
• Navigate and list items from Ableton's browser
  • Load instruments, effects, and samples directly
  • Import audio files into audio tracks

docs.title: 🎤 Voice & Audio Generation
docs.text:
• Text-to-Speech integration via ElevenLabs
  • Custom voice creation and cloning
  • Sound effects generation
  • Direct import into Ableton sessions

docs.title: ⚡ Extensible Framework
docs.text:
• Build custom Ableton controllers
  • Ultra-low latency UDP protocol
  • Example: XY Mouse Controller for real-time parameter control

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
graph TB
    A[You: Natural Language] --> B[AI Assistant]
    B --> C[MCP Server]
    C --> D[Ableton Remote Script]
    D --> E[Ableton Live API]
    E --> F[🎵 Your Music]

    G[ElevenLabs AI] --> H[Generated Audio]
    H --> C
  1. You issue a command in plain English to your AI assistant
  2. AI Assistant understands intent and calls the appropriate MCP tool
  3. MCP Server constructs a specific JSON command
  4. Ableton Remote Script receives the command via socket connection
  5. Remote Script executes using the official Ableton Live API
  6. Change happens instantly in your Ableton session

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for all available MCP tools in Ableton MCP Extended.

docs.title: get_session_info
docs.text:
Get detailed information about the current Ableton session.

Returns:

  • tempo: Current tempo (BPM)
  • track_count: Number of tracks
  • tracks: Array of track objects with index, name, device_count

Example:

"Get information about my current Ableton session"

docs.title: start_playback
docs.text:
Start Ableton Live playback.

Example:

"Start playback"

docs.title: stop_playback
docs.text:
Stop Ableton Live playback.

Example:

"Stop playback"

docs.title: set_tempo
docs.text:
Set the session tempo.

Parameters:

  • tempo (float): New tempo in BPM (typically 60-200)

Example:

"Set the tempo to 128 BPM"

docs.title: create_midi_track
docs.text:
Create a new MIDI track.

Parameters:

  • index (int, optional): Position to insert track (-1 for end, default: -1)

Example:

"Create a new MIDI track"
"Create a MIDI track at position 2"

docs.title: get_track_info
docs.text:
Get detailed information about a specific track.

Parameters:

  • track_index (int): Index of the track (0-based)

Returns:

  • index: Track index
  • name: Track name
  • devices: Array of device objects
  • device_count: Number of devices

Example:

"Get information about track 0"

docs.title: set_track_name
docs.text:
Set the name of a track.

Parameters:

  • track_index (int): Index of the track
  • name (str): New track name

Example:

"Rename track 0 to 'Bass'"

docs.title: create_clip
docs.text:
Create a new MIDI clip in a track's clip slot.

Parameters:

  • track_index (int): Index of the track
  • clip_index (int): Clip slot index
  • length (float, optional): Length in beats (default: 4.0)

Example:

"Create a 4-bar MIDI clip on track 0, slot 0"

docs.title: set_clip_name
docs.text:
Set the name of a clip.

Parameters:

  • track_index (int): Index of the track
  • clip_index (int): Clip slot index
  • name (str): New clip name

Example:

"Name the clip in track 0, slot 0 as 'Bassline'"

docs.title: add_notes_to_clip
docs.text:
Add MIDI notes to a clip.

Parameters:

  • track_index (int): Index of the track
  • clip_index (int): Clip slot index
  • notes (array): Array of note objects

Note Object Format:

{
  "pitch": 60,         // MIDI note number (0-127)
  "start_time": 0.0,   // Start position in beats
  "duration": 0.5,     // Length in beats
  "velocity": 100,     // Velocity (0-127)
  "mute": false        // Mute state (optional)
}

Example:

"Add notes to clip: C3 at beat 0, E3 at beat 1, G3 at beat 2"

docs.title: load_instrument_or_effect
docs.text:
Load an instrument or effect onto a track from the browser.

Parameters:

  • track_index (int): Index of the track
  • uri (str): Browser URI or path to the device

Example:

"Load the instrument at path 'Instruments/Synth/Lead' on track 0"

docs.title: get_browser_tree
docs.text:
Get a hierarchical tree of browser categories.

Parameters:

  • category_type (str, optional): Type of categories (default: "all")
  • "all": All categories
  • "instruments": Virtual instruments
  • "sounds": Presets and samples
  • "drums": Drum kits
  • "audio_effects": Audio effects
  • "midi_effects": MIDI effects

Example:

"Show me the browser tree for instruments"

docs.title: get_browser_items_at_path
docs.text:
Get items at a specific browser path.

Parameters:

  • path (str): Browser path (e.g., "Sounds/Piano")

Example:

"What items are in the Sounds/Piano folder?"

docs.title: load_drum_kit
docs.text:
Load a drum kit onto a track.

Parameters:

  • track_index (int): Index of the track
  • kit_uri (str): URI or path to the drum kit

Example:

"Load the 808 drum kit on track 1"

docs.title: Parameter Values
docs.text:
All device parameter values are normalized to the 0.0-1.0 range:

Value Meaning 0.0 Minimum (fully counter-clockwise) 0.5 Middle position 1.0 Maximum (fully clockwise)

Converting Values

The server automatically converts normalized values to the device's actual range. You don't need to know the min/max values - just use 0.0 to 1.0!

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
All tools return error messages in a readable format when something goes wrong:

"Error creating track: Track index out of range"
"Error loading device: Browser path not found"

Common errors:

  • Index out of range: Track/clip/device index doesn't exist
  • Connection refused: Ableton Live not running or Remote Script not loaded
  • Invalid parameter: Value outside allowed range or wrong type
  • Browser path not found: Invalid browser URI or path

docs.title: Track Index
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Range: 0 to track_count - 1
  • Zero-indexed (first track = 0)

docs.title: Clip Index
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Range: 0 to available clip slots
  • Zero-indexed (first clip slot = 0)

docs.title: Device Index
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Range: 0 to device_count - 1
  • Zero-indexed (first device = 0)

docs.title: Parameter Index
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Range: 0 to parameter_count - 1
  • Zero-indexed (first parameter = 0)

docs.title: Normalized Value
docs.text:
• Type: float
  • Range: 0.0 to 1.0
  • Used for all parameter values

docs.title: Time (Beats)
docs.text:
• Type: float
  • Range: 0.0 to clip length
  • Measured in beats (quarter notes)

docs.title: MIDI Note
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Range: 0 to 127
  • Middle C (C4) = 60

docs.title: Velocity
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Range: 0 to 127
  • Typical: 64-127 (medium to loud)

docs.title: Advanced: UDP Server Tools
docs.text:
The UDP server provides high-performance, real-time parameter control.

UDP Server Required

These tools require the AbletonMCP_UDP Remote Script to be installed and enabled.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Ultra-low latency (~1-5ms)
  • Batch parameter updates
  • Real-time performance control
  • No response required (fire-and-forget)

See UDP High Performance for details.

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
• Follow PEP 8
  • Use meaningful variable names
  • Add docstrings to functions and classes
  • Keep functions focused and small

Example:

@mcp.tool()
def create_midi_track(ctx: Context, index: int = -1) -> str:
    """
    Create a new MIDI track in Ableton Live.

    Parameters:
    - index: Position to insert the track (-1 for end)

    Returns:
    - Success message with track index
    """
    try:
        ableton = get_ableton_connection()
        result = ableton.send_command("create_midi_track", {"index": index})
        return f"Created MIDI track at index {result.get('index', index)}"
    except Exception as e:
        return f"Error creating MIDI track: {str(e)}"

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Use clear, concise language
  • Include code examples
  • Add warnings for experimental features
  • Use proper Markdown formatting

docs.title: Adding a New MCP Tool
docs.text:
1. Add the tool in MCP_Server/server.py:
@mcp.tool()
def your_new_tool(ctx: Context, param1: str, param2: int) -> str:
    """
    Description of what your tool does.

    Parameters:
    - param1: Description
    - param2: Description
    """
    try:
        ableton = get_ableton_connection()
        result = ableton.send_command("your_command", {
            "param1": param1,
            "param2": param2
        })
        return f"Success: {result}"
    except Exception as e:
        return f"Error: {str(e)}"
  1. Implement in Remote Script (AbletonMCP_UDP/__init__.py):
def _your_command(self, param1, param2):
    """Implementation using Ableton Live API"""
    try:
        # Use self._song and Ableton API here
        result = {"success": True}
        return result
    except Exception as e:
        self.log_message(f"Error in _your_command: {e}")
        raise

  1. Add command handling in _process_command method

  2. Update documentation in docs/api-reference.md

  3. Test thoroughly

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: Get Ableton MCP Extended running in under 10 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you start, make sure you have:

  • Ableton Live 11 or newer (any edition - Intro, Standard, or Suite)
  • Python 3.10 or higher (Download here)
  • Git command-line tool
  • Claude Desktop or Cursor IDE (Claude | Cursor)
  • 15 minutes of uninterrupted time
  • Administrator privileges on your computer

docs.title: Step 1: Get the Code
docs.text:
Clone the repository and install the Python package:

git clone https://github.com/uisato/ableton-mcp-extended.git
cd ableton-mcp-extended
pip install -e .

Verify Installation:

python -c "from mcp.server.fastmcp import FastMCP; print('✅ Python package installed successfully!')"

docs.title: Step 2: Install the Ableton Remote Script
docs.text: Your Ableton Remote Scripts location depends on your operating system:

docs.title: 🪟 Windows
docs.text:
C:\Users\[YourUsername]\Documents\Ableton\User Library\Remote Scripts\

Quick way to find it:

  1. Open File Explorer
  2. Paste this in the address bar: %USERPROFILE%\Documents\Ableton\User Library\Remote Scripts
  3. Press Enter

docs.title: 🍎 macOS
docs.text:
~/Library/Preferences/Ableton/Live [Version]/User Remote Scripts/

Quick way to find it:

  1. Open Finder
  2. Press Cmd + Shift + G
  3. Paste: ~/Library/Preferences/Ableton/
  4. Navigate to your Live version folder, then User Remote Scripts

docs.title: Install the Main Remote Script
docs.text:
1. Create folder: In your Remote Scripts directory, create a new folder called AbletonMCP
  2. Copy file: Copy AbletonMCP_Remote_Script/__init__.py into the AbletonMCP folder

Your folder structure should look like:

Remote Scripts/
├── AbletonMCP/
│   └── __init__.py
└── (other scripts...)

Tip

Double-check this folder structure - it's the most common source of installation issues.

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Ableton Live
docs.text:
Enable the Remote Script:

  1. Open or restart Ableton Live
  2. Navigate to Preferences (Ctrl + , or Cmd + ,)
  3. Go to the Link, Tempo & MIDI tab
  4. In an empty Control Surface slot, select AbletonMCP from the dropdown menu
  5. Set the Input and Output for the AbletonMCP surface to None
  6. Close the Preferences window

When the script is loaded correctly, you will see: "AbletonMCP: Listening for commands on port 9877"

docs.title: Step 4: Connect Your AI Assistant
docs.text:
Choose your preferred AI assistant:

Claude DesktopCursor IDE
  1. Open Claude Desktop
  2. Go to Claude → Settings → Developer
  3. Click "Edit Config"
  4. Replace the entire content with:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "AbletonMCP": {
      "command": "python3",
      "args": [
        "/path/to/ableton-mcp-extended/MCP_Server/server.py"
      ]
    }
  }
}
  1. Update the path with your actual installation path
  2. Save and restart Claude Desktop

Finding Your Installation Path (macOS): 

# In your ableton-mcp-extended folder, run:
echo $PWD/MCP_Server/server.py

Finding Your Installation Path (Windows): 

# In your ableton-mcp-extended folder, run:
echo %CD%\MCP_Server\server.py

  1. Open Cursor
  2. Go to Settings → MCP
  3. Add new MCP server:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "AbletonMCP": {
      "command": "python3",
      "args": [
        "/path/to/ableton-mcp-extended/MCP_Server/server.py"
      ]
    }
  }
}
  1. Save settings

docs.title: Verify AI Connection
docs.text:
For Claude Desktop: Look for a 🔨 hammer icon in the chat interface - this indicates MCP tools are loaded.

For Cursor: You'll see a green dot next to the MCP server icon.

Note

You might have to restart your AI assistant for changes to take effect.

docs.title: Step 5: Test Your Installation
docs.text:
Try these commands in your AI assistant:

Basic Tests

  1. "Get information about my current Ableton session"

  2. Should return details about your Ableton project

  3. "Create a new MIDI track"

  4. Should create a new track in Ableton

  5. "What tracks do I currently have?"

  6. Should list your tracks

If all three commands work correctly, congratulations! 🎉 Your installation is complete.

docs.text:
For ultra-low latency parameter control (like the XY Mouse Controller):

  1. Install UDP Remote Script:
  2. Create folder: Remote Scripts/AbletonMCP_UDP/

  3. Copy: AbletonMCP_UDP/__init__.py

  4. Configure in Ableton:

  5. Add another Control Surface: "AbletonMCP_UDP"

docs.title: 🎤 ElevenLabs Voice Integration
docs.text:
Add AI voice generation to your workflow:

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
AbletonMCP not found in Control Surface list

Possible causes: - Remote Script not in correct folder - File permissions issue - Incorrect folder name

Solutions:

  1. Verify folder path: Remote Scripts/AbletonMCP/__init__.py
  2. Check file permissions (should be readable)
  3. Restart Ableton Live completely
  4. Check Ableton's log for error messages
No hammer icon in Claude Desktop

Possible causes: - Incorrect path in config file - Python not in system PATH - MCP server file missing

Solutions:

  1. Verify Python installation: python3 --version
  2. Check absolute path to server.py file
  3. Use full path on Windows: C:\\path\\to\\file
  4. Restart Claude Desktop after config changes
Connection refused or Socket error

Possible causes: - Ableton not running - Remote Script not loaded - Firewall blocking connection

Solutions:

  1. Make sure Ableton Live is running
  2. Verify Remote Script is selected in Ableton preferences
  3. Check firewall settings
  4. Try restarting both Ableton and your AI assistant
Python not found error

Solutions:

  1. Install Python: Download from python.org
  2. Add to PATH: During installation, check "Add Python to PATH"
  3. Verify installation: Open terminal, type python3 --version
  4. Use full path: If still issues, use full Python path in config

docs.title: Advanced Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Test Components Individually:

# Test Python installation
python3 --version

# Test MCP server directly
python3 MCP_Server/server.py

# Test Ableton connection (with Ableton running)
python3 -c "import socket; s = socket.socket(); s.connect(('localhost', 9877)); print('✅ Connected')"

docs.title: Natural Language Tips
docs.text: Ableton MCP Extended works best when you:

docs.title: ✅ Be Specific
docs.text:
Good: "Create a MIDI track at index 2 and name it 'Melody'"
Less Good: "Make a track"

docs.title: ✅ Use Musical Terms
docs.text:
Good: "Add a C major triad starting at beat 1"
Less Good: "Add some notes"

docs.title: ✅ Break Down Complex Tasks
docs.text:
Good:
1. "Create a MIDI track called 'Bass'"
2. "Load the 'Electric Bass' instrument"
3. "Create a 4-bar clip in slot 0"
4. "Add bass notes..."

docs.title: Example: XY Mouse Controller
docs.text:
The repository includes a complete example of a custom controller:

Location: experimental_tools/xy_mouse_controller/

docs.title: Running the Example

cd experimental_tools/xy_mouse_controller
pip install -r requirements.txt
python mouse_parameter_controller_udp.py

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
1. Your Custom Tool (Python, JavaScript, etc.)
  2. UDP/TCP Communication (Socket connection)
  3. Ableton Remote Script (Receives commands)
  4. Ableton Live API (Executes changes)
Your Tool → UDP/TCP → Remote Script → Ableton API → Changes in Live

docs.title: 1. Choose a Protocol
docs.text:
TCP (Recommended for beginners): - Reliable delivery - Request/response pattern - Easier to debug

UDP (For advanced real-time control): - Ultra-low latency - Fire-and-forget - High throughput

docs.title: 2. Establish Connection
docs.text:
Python TCP Example: 

import socket
import json

def send_command(command_type, params):
    # Connect to TCP server
    sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
    sock.connect(("localhost", 9877))

    # Send command
    command = {
        "type": command_type,
        "params": params
    }
    sock.sendall(json.dumps(command).encode())

    # Receive response
    response = sock.recv(8192).decode()
    sock.close()
    return json.loads(response)

Python UDP Example: 

import socket
import json

def send_udp_command(command_type, params):
    sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_DGRAM)
    command = {
        "type": command_type,
        "params": params
    }
    sock.sendto(
        json.dumps(command).encode(),
        ("localhost", 9878)
    )

docs.title: 3. Implement Your Logic
docs.text:
class CustomController:
    def __init__(self):
        self.sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_DGRAM)

    def map_gesture_to_parameter(self, x, y):
        # Map X coordinate to filter cutoff
        cutoff = x / screen_width  # Normalize to 0-1

        # Map Y coordinate to resonance
        resonance = 1.0 - (y / screen_height)  # Normalize and invert

        # Update both parameters
        self.batch_update(0, 0, [5, 6], [cutoff, resonance])

    def batch_update(self, track, device, params, values):
        command = {
            "type": "batch_set_device_parameters",
            "params": {
                "track_index": track,
                "device_index": device,
                "parameter_indices": params,
                "values": values
            }
        }
        self.sock.sendto(
            json.dumps(command).encode(),
            ("localhost", 9878)
        )

docs.text:

def trigger_clip(track_index, clip_index):
    send_command("fire_clip", {
        "track_index": track_index,
        "clip_index": clip_index
    })

docs.title: 2. Parameter Randomizer
docs.text:
Randomly modulate device parameters:

import random

def randomize_parameters(track, device, param_count):
    params = list(range(param_count))
    values = [random.random() for _ in params]

    send_udp_command("batch_set_device_parameters", {
        "track_index": track,
        "device_index": device,
        "parameter_indices": params,
        "values": values
    })

docs.title: 3. Gesture Recorder
docs.text:
Record and playback parameter gestures:

class GestureRecorder:
    def __init__(self):
        self.recording = []

    def record_gesture(self, param_values):
        self.recording.append({
            "timestamp": time.time(),
            "values": param_values
        })

    def playback(self, track, device):
        start_time = time.time()
        for event in self.recording:
            # Wait until timestamp
            while time.time() - start_time < event["timestamp"]:
                time.sleep(0.001)

            # Apply parameter values
            send_udp_command("batch_set_device_parameters", {
                "track_index": track,
                "device_index": device,
                "parameter_indices": list(range(len(event["values"]))),
                "values": event["values"]
            })

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
Use UDP for Real-Time

For >30 updates per second, use UDP for lower latency.

Batch Updates

Update multiple parameters in one command using batch_set_device_parameters.

Throttle Updates

Limit update rate to what's perceptually necessary (100-200 Hz max).

docs.title: Reliability
docs.text:
Handle Disconnection

Check if Ableton is running before sending commands.

Validate Parameters

Ensure parameter indices and values are valid before sending.

docs.title: User Experience
docs.text:
Provide Feedback

Visual or audio feedback helps users understand what's happening.

Error Handling

Gracefully handle errors and connection issues.

docs.title: Multi-Parameter Mapping
docs.text:
Map one input to multiple parameters:

def map_one_to_many(input_value):
    # Map to multiple parameters with different curves
    cutoff = input_value  # Linear
    resonance = input_value ** 2  # Exponential
    drive = math.sin(input_value * math.pi)  # Sine wave

    batch_update(0, 0, [5, 6, 7], [cutoff, resonance, drive])

docs.title: Parameter Smoothing
docs.text:
Smooth parameter changes for better sound:

class Smoother:
    def __init__(self, smooth_time=0.1):
        self.current = 0.0
        self.target = 0.0
        self.smooth_time = smooth_time

    def set_target(self, value):
        self.target = value

    def update(self, delta_time):
        # Exponential smoothing
        alpha = 1.0 - math.exp(-delta_time / self.smooth_time)
        self.current += (self.target - self.current) * alpha
        return self.current

docs.title: High-Performance UDP Server
docs.text: Ultra-low latency parameter control for real-time performance and interactive tools.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The UDP server provides:

  • Ultra-low latency: 1-5ms response time
  • High throughput: Handle hundreds of updates per second
  • Real-time control: Perfect for performance and interactive tools
  • Fire-and-forget: No response required for maximum speed

docs.title: When to Use UDP
docs.text:
Use the UDP server when you need:

  • ✅ Real-time parameter control
  • ✅ High-frequency updates (100+ per second)
  • ✅ Interactive controllers
  • ✅ Live performance tools
  • ✅ Mouse/gesture control

Use the standard TCP server when you need:

  • ✅ Reliable delivery
  • ✅ Response confirmation
  • ✅ Complex queries
  • ✅ Session information
  • ✅ Browser operations

docs.title: 1. Install the UDP Remote Script
docs.text:
Copy the UDP Remote Script to Ableton's Remote Scripts folder:

macOS: 

cp AbletonMCP_UDP/__init__.py \
  ~/Library/Preferences/Ableton/Live\ X/User\ Remote\ Scripts/AbletonMCP_UDP/

Windows: 

copy AbletonMCP_UDP\__init__.py \
  %USERPROFILE%\Documents\Ableton\User Library\Remote Scripts\AbletonMCP_UDP\

docs.title: 2. Configure in Ableton
docs.text:
1. Open Ableton Live Preferences
  2. Go to Link, Tempo & MIDI
  3. Add a new Control Surface: Select AbletonMCP_UDP
  4. Set Input/Output to None

docs.title: 3. Verify
docs.text: You should see: "AbletonMCP: TCP on 9877, UDP on 9878"

docs.title: Direct UDP Communication
docs.text:
The UDP server listens on port 9878 (TCP is on 9877).

Example Python code:

import socket
import json

# Create UDP socket
sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_DGRAM)

# Send parameter update
command = {
    "type": "set_device_parameter",
    "params": {
        "track_index": 0,
        "device_index": 0,
        "parameter_index": 5,
        "value": 0.75
    }
}

sock.sendto(json.dumps(command).encode(), ("localhost", 9878))

docs.title: Example Architecture
docs.text:
import socket
import json

class AbletonController:
    def __init__(self):
        self.sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_DGRAM)
        self.host = "localhost"
        self.port = 9878

    def set_parameter(self, track, device, param, value):
        command = {
            "type": "set_device_parameter",
            "params": {
                "track_index": track,
                "device_index": device,
                "parameter_index": param,
                "value": value
            }
        }
        self.sock.sendto(
            json.dumps(command).encode(),
            (self.host, self.port)
        )

# Use it
controller = AbletonController()
controller.set_parameter(0, 0, 5, 0.75)

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Batch Updates

Use batch_set_device_parameters for updating multiple parameters simultaneously - it's more efficient than individual updates.

Fire-and-Forget

UDP doesn't confirm delivery. For critical operations, use the TCP server instead.

Network Reliability

UDP packets can be lost or arrive out of order. This is acceptable for real-time control where latest value matters most.

docs.title: Coexistence
docs.text:
Both TCP and UDP servers can run simultaneously:

  • TCP (9877): Standard MCP operations
  • UDP (9878): Real-time parameter control

Use both for maximum flexibility!

docs.text:
Shift notes up or down by semitones.

- C major triad at beat 0

docs.title: MIDI Note Reference
docs.text:
Quick reference for common notes:

Note Number Frequency Use Case C2 36 65.4 Hz Sub bass C3 48 130.8 Hz Bass C4 60 261.6 Hz Middle C C5 72 523.3 Hz Melody C6 84 1047 Hz High melody

Intervals: - Octave = +12 semitones - Fifth = +7 semitones - Major third = +4 semitones - Minor third = +3 semitones

docs.title: Musical Time
docs.text:
Time in clips is measured in beats (quarter notes):

Value Duration 0.25 16th note 0.5 8th note 1.0 Quarter note 2.0 Half note 4.0 Whole note

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Building Chords

Common chord intervals from root:

  • Major: 0, 4, 7 (C-E-G)
  • Minor: 0, 3, 7 (C-Eb-G)
  • Diminished: 0, 3, 6
  • Augmented: 0, 4, 8

Velocity

Velocity affects note loudness:

  • 0-40: Very quiet (pp-p)
  • 41-80: Medium (mp-mf)
  • 81-100: Loud (f)
  • 101-127: Very loud (ff-fff)

Clip Slot Indices

Clip slots are zero-indexed like tracks:

  • First clip slot = 0
  • Second clip slot = 1
  • etc.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Tempo Range

While you can set any tempo, typical ranges are: - Slow: 60-90 BPM (ballads, ambient) - Medium: 90-120 BPM (pop, rock) - Fast: 120-180 BPM (electronic, dance) - Very fast: 180+ BPM (drum & bass, hardstyle)

Session Info Updates

Session info reflects the current state when called. If you make changes, call it again to see updated information.

docs.title: Track Indices
docs.text:
Zero-Indexed

Tracks are zero-indexed, meaning:

  • First track = 0
  • Second track = 1
  • Third track = 2
  • etc.

Finding Track Indices

Use get_session_info to see all tracks with their indices: 

"Get session info"

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Naming Convention

Use clear, descriptive names for tracks:

  • ✅ "Bass", "Lead Synth", "Kick Drum"
  • ❌ "Track 1", "untitled", "asdf"

Track Limits

Ableton Live supports many tracks, but performance may vary based on:

  • Computer specifications
  • Number of devices per track
  • Sample rate and buffer size
